title: Kroger becomes latest retail giant to stop selling e-cigarettes following spate of vaping deaths
text:
Supermarket chain Kroger is joining Walmart and other retail giants by ending the sales of e-cigarettes in its stores and fuel centers, amid a series of mysterious vaping-related deaths across the US which have sparked regulatory uncertainty.

The company, which also owns Harris Teeter, Fred Meyer and other store brands, announced Monday that it will cease all e-cigarette sales after selling through its current inventory.

A spokesperson for Kroger cited the ‘mounting questions and increasingly-complex regulatory environment’ as the motive behind its decision.

The grocer, however, confirmed they will continue to sell tobacco products throughout their stores.

The e-cigarette industry has come under increasing public and regulatory scrutiny in the past few months, following a spate of deadly vaping illnesses that have claimed the lives of 19 different people across the US.

It’s thought that more than 1,000 others have suffered serious lung injuries in the outbreak - which dates back to March - as a result of excessive vaping.

Most of the patients identified vaped THC, the active ingredient in marijuana, and 17 percent exclusively used nicotine, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

‘I think we really have the feeling right now that there may be a lot of different nasty things in e-cigarette or vaping products, and they may cause different harms in the lung,’ Anne Schuchat, a senior official with CDC, said in a statement.

Teen vaping has been deemed an 'epidemic' by US health officials, and we're only beginning to learn what immediate and long-term consequences the devices might have for the millions of young people using them.

Because information has been so limited, the CDC hasn’t been able to draw any definitive conclusions about the nature of the injuries and who is most vulnerable to the illness.

Kroger’s move comes just one month after Walmart announced it would no longer cell e-cigarettes in any of its stores – and Sam’s Clubs locations – again citing ‘regulatory complexities’

Some 80 percent of the Americans who have developed vaping-related lung injuries are under the age of 35, and 16 percent are teenagers 18 or under.

Deaths have occurred in at least 16 states, with the latest confirmed in Connecticut.

While the causes remain unknown, health officials believe a chemical exposure related to an oil-based additive may be to blame.

Initially marketed as a tool to help smokers quit cigarettes, e-cigs have exploded in popularity in the last five years, particularly among teenagers and young adults.

Some critics have accused companies such as Juul of purposely flavoring its products to appeal to teens directly.

New York and Michigan have already banned the sales of flavored vaping products, while the Trump administration has announced plans to remove all flavored e-cigarettes from store shelves with a federal ban.

Kroger’s move comes just one month after Walmart announced it would no longer sell e-cigarettes in any of its stores – and Sam’s Clubs locations – again citing ‘regulatory complexities’.

Rite Aid made a similar move in April, banishing e-cigarettes from its stores nationwide.

Earlier this year, Walmart, Walgreens and Ride Aid all announced plans to raise the minimum age to buy tobacco up to 21, after a dozen states already passed motions to do so through legislation.
